subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Test the side-effect of the work.  This may involve querying an instance variable or passing in a mock object somewhere to collect the results of the work.
messageBody:
juwo77 wrote:

>
> 1) JUnit seems to test "functions" that return a value. How will you
> test "procedures" that do work instead?

Test the side-effect of the work. This may involve querying an instance
variable or passing in a mock object somewhere to collect the results of the
work. The latter is sometimes useful to avoid breaking encapsulation.


>
> (It is 'against the rules' to change the design of them to return
> values - a testing tool should not force code changes.)

(I'll assume you are the designer in this case.)

JUnit is as much a design tool as it is a testing tool. Your tests are
effectively asking the code questions, the expected answers to which are
asserted. If it's difficult to ask a question such that the right answer can
easily be asserted, then the code is communicating something very important
about the design. Writing tests first, I'm constantly changing the design of
the code, in very small steps.


> 2) How will you test procedures that are composed of several
> functions?

I generally have a test for each method, and then a test for the composite
method. Sometimes not. It's a judgment call. For me, it really depends on
the test-first path I'm on when those methods are born.

I recommend trying both ways and see what works best for you.


>
> 3) Can JUnit ever replace stepping thru with a debugger?
>

I can't remember the last time I used a debugger. I used to use a debugger
quite often to step through the code and manually inspect that the variables
along the way contained the values I expected. Once in a while I'd even get
lazy and dump a System.out.println() somewhere in the call stack to list all
the variables and their values. Worse yet, I'd go through this sanity check
every time something changed. Then I recognized this as nothing more than
manually comparing expected vs. actual values.

So I started to resist the urge to fire up the debugger and instead try to
write an automated test. Sometimes I just put the assertion directly in the
code as a way to start thinking about what I would need to write a unit
test. Often times the design changes to make the code more testable. Short
and cohesive methods were one immediate improvement. In return the design
seems to exhibit some desirable properties.

Writing the tests first really speeds up this feedback loop. It distills
testable code and better designs from the beginning. I write all new code
this way these days. If I'm debugging existing code, I'll try my best to
find a way to write automated tests to retain the value of the debugging
session over time.

Mike
